column1: Data Supplied By: National Livestock Reporting Service
Data source: National Livestock Reporting Service
Please see terms of use here: https://www.mla.com.au/general/Terms-and-conditions/data-and-information/

There were approximately 3,100 export and 570 young cattle penned representing an increase of 1,550 head week-on-week. The usual buying group was rejoined by a domestic processor after a long absence and all operated in a cheaper market in places. Quality was good with more prime cattle penned while manufacturing steers represented a large proportion of the bullock sale. The best Euro trade cattle sold firm while the main run of young cattle eased 5c to 15c to processors and up to 20c/kg to feeder orders. Grown steers and bullocks eased 6c/kg. Manufacturing steers lost 4c to 6c/kg. Heavy grown heifers gave back 7c/kg. Cows eased 5c to 15c/kg. Heavy bulls sold generally firm. 

Vealers sold from 310c to 400c/kg. Yearling trade steers made between 340c and 376c/kg. Yearling heifers to the trade sold between 318c and 366c/kg. Grown steers made from 340c to 389c/kg. Bullocks sold from 360c to 394c/kg. Heavy grown heifers made between 326c and 350c/kg. 

Heavy Friesian manufacturing steers sold between 294c and 331c with the crossbred portion between 304c and 388c/kg. Most light and medium weight cows made from 204c to 291c/kg. Heavy weight cows sold mostly from 266c to 320c after a top of 330c/kg. Heavy bulls made between 250c and 325c/kg. 

Market reporter: Brendan Fletcher.
